    aggregate validate

    rapidcycler

    Read this page and more on the website: https://atkinsbd.github.io/rapidcycler/

    The protocol, data dictionary, table templates, and other information that suppport the use of this package can be found on the GVDN extranet: RCA II (2024)

    The goal of rapidcycler is to bring together a number of methodologies and functions that are used to perform Rapid Cycle Analysis (RCA).

    The current version of the package includes functionality to validate and aggregate line list data into a de-identified format for sharing with GVDN. There is also additional functionality to produce synthetic line list data, though this has not been thoroughly tested and as such should only be used for illustrative/testing purposes.

    Future versions will include functions to perform sequential analysis using maximised sequential probability ratio tests (MaxSPRT), visualise results, and produce reports. A Shiny app is also planned to aid in the regular communication of results. Sites are not required to use these functions, as the analysis and dissemination of results will be performed by GVDN, however they are provided for transparency and so that sites may utilise them as they please.

    Installation

    You can install rapidcycler in two ways:

    1. Tarball installation

    If you are unable to connect to GitHub from within your working environment, this is the method you will use. A single zipped file (tarball) will be made available for you to download (here) and import into your environment. This will contain the source code for the package, and can be opened and checked, however should not be edited. Once saved in your environment, the package can be installed with the following command:

    # EDIT THE FILE PATH AND NAME AS NECESSARY
install.packages("~/Documents/rapidcycler_1.0.0.0.tar.gz", repos = NULL, type="source")

    To update the package, the process of downloading, importing, and installing the tarball must be repeated.

    2. Directly from GitHub

    If you are able to connect to GitHub from within your working environment, this method offers a more streamlined way to install and update the package. You will need to have access to the GitHub repository to use this method.

    devtools::install_github("Global-Vaccine-Data-Network/rapidcycler", build_vignettes = TRUE)

    Dependencies

    There are several other R packages which need to be installed before installing rapidcycler:

    • clock
    • data.table
    • dplyr
    • fst
    • magrittr
    • rlang
    • stringr

    Loading and using

    Once the package has been installed, it can be loaded and used in the same way as any R package. There are two main ways to do this:

    1. Load the whole package and its functions using library(rapidcycler). You can then call functions by name, e.g.Â aggregate_data().

    2. Use specific functions only with the :: notation, e.g.Â rapidcycler::aggregate_data().

    The functions you can access using the above methods are called exported functions, and are the primary functions that you should interact with. However, there are also many non-exported, internal functions, which do a lot of work behind the scenes. These functions are also documented (see the â€˜Referenceâ€™ tab on the website, or help page in RStudio), and can be accessed using the ::: notation. For example, rapidcycler:::convert_date_to_number(date), will convert a Date object to an 8-digit integer representation of that date. It is not necessary to explore or explicitly use these functions, but they are there if you wish to.

    Package structure

    The package is split into 6 main parts, each with a separate purpose:

    1. Aggregate: aggregate line list data into an appropriate, de-identified format for sharing

    2. Validate: validate the input datasets before performing aggregation

    3. Generate: generate synthetic input data for testing and illustrative purposes

    4. Configure (expected in future version)

    5. Analyse (expected in future version)

    6. Visualise (expected in future version)

    Basic usage

    To participate in RCA, sites are only required to interact with the aggregation part of the package. The other functionalities will be used by GVDN to perform the analyses and report results, however will be provided to sites to make use of if they wish to (expected in future version).

    For an in depth explanation of the aggregation functions and examples, refer to the aggregate vignette: this can be found under the â€˜Articlesâ€™ tab of the website, or by running vignette("aggregate", "rapidcycler") in RStudio (once package has been installed).

    Input datasets

    The starting point for interacting with the package is to obtain 3 data.table objects, containing information on patients, vaccinations, and AESI outcomes.

    A full data dictionary can be found here: RCA II (2024), and a summary of the input dataset structures is given below:

    patient_data

    Column name Column type Description
    PID character Individual or person-level identifier, often pseudo-anonymised
    DOB 8 digit integer Date of birth of patient
    SEX character The biological sex at birth of the person
    ENROL_DATE 8 digit integer Date the patient entered the cohort from which they are eligible for inclusion in the study (independent of study dates). If eligible from birth, can be set to NA and will default to DOB
    CENSOR_DATE 8 digit integer Date the patient left the cohort from which they are no longer eligible for inclusion in the study (independent of study dates)
    CENSOR_TYPE character Type of censoring (missing, dead, travelled, or emigrated)

    vaccination_data

    Column name Column type Description
    PID character Individual or person-level identifier, often pseudo-anonymised
    V_DATE 8 digit integer Date of vaccination
    V_BRAND character Code specifying the brand of vaccine given

    outcome_data

    Column name Column type Description
    PID character Individual or person-level identifier, often pseudo-anonymised
    AESI character Short name of AESI outcome (Tier 2 unless otherwise specified)
    EVENT_DATE 8 digit integer Diagnosis date through healthcare providers
    ENCOUNTER_TYPE numeric Source of the diagnosis information from healthcare setting (code from 1-4)

    Recommended folder structure

    There is no restriction on the folder structure you use within your local environment. However, in case it is useful, we provide the the outline of a structure that we recommend below. Folder names can be changed as you please, but note that the name of the folder created by the aggregate_data() function should not be changed (details in the aggregate vignette).

    Advanced usage (vignettes)

    For explanations and examples relating to the other functionalities within the package, please see the included vignettes.

    You can browse all vignettes using browseVignettes("rapidcycler") in RStudio, or under the â€˜Articlesâ€™ tab on the website.
